info.name: PayPal REST API Simulation - Payouts
info.description:
The PayPal sandbox environment enables you to pass specific information in a request to trigger simulated positive and negative test scenarios. The simulated responses mimic actual API responses without calling downstream services. You can handle these responses in your code to manage your buyer’s experience.

This collection provides 4 examples of different simulations. For a complete list of negative and positive simulations you can send, visit our [Test Payouts developer docs](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/payouts/integrate/test-payouts/#show-payout).

request.description: The PayPal REST API uses the OAuth 2.0 protocol to authorize calls. OAuth is an open standard that many companies use to provide secure access to protected resources. When you create a REST app in the PayPal Developer Dashboard, PayPal generates a set of OAuth client_id and secret credentials for your app for both the sandbox and live environments. In the Postman app, you pass these as username and password Basic Auth credentials in the Authorization tab of the GET access token request. Postman will base64 encode the credentials for you and add the Basic Auth header to the request. In exchange for these credentials, the PayPal authorization server issues a Bearer token, called access_token, that you use for authorization when you make REST API requests. The access_token enables you to complete actions on behalf and with the approval of the resource owner.

header.value: X-PP-SILOVER=name%3DSANDBOX3.API.1%26silo_version%3D1880%26app%3Dapiplatformproxyserv%26TIME%3D1042742363%26HTTP_X_PP_AZ_LOCATOR%3Dsandbox.slc; Expires=Mon, 26 Nov 2018 17:28:39 GMT; domain=.paypal.com; path=/; Secure; HttpOnly

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description: This is a positive simulation that uses the POSPYO001 value and the JSON pointer method in the body of the request to simulate a positive payout creation payload with a 201 response. The access_token value you generated in Step 1 is captured as a variable and used as the Bearer Token to authenticate this request.

request.description: This is a positive simulation for Payouts to Venmo receivers that uses the POSPYO003 value and the JSON pointer method in the body of the request to simulate a positive payout creation payload with a 201 response. The access_token value you generated in Step 1 is captured as a variable and used as the Bearer Token to authenticate this request.
